topic_details.title: Growing Old in the Newborn Universe

posts.desciription: Originally published at: Growing Old in the Newborn Universe

Why was Mr. Kohler showing his friend the heart of Chicago from behind the wheel of a car?   Maybe he could connect with the universe better, and impress his friend more if they got out and walked or used public transit - notably the “El” which is as iconic at London double-decker buses.
Yet, I bet Mr. Kohler considers himself a climate activist.
Nice piece, Mr. Kohler, though “bleed wonder” does not work for me.  Ask your daughter what she thinks.  And words are saxifrage.  They can break rocks.

I don’t know why. Koehler’s words seem to shoot right over, around, or straight through my head without leaving any palpable trace. It’s not as if his rap annoys me; It’s as if he’s lapsing into so much creole – a dialect or language which is tricky for me to keep up with – that I lose track of where he’s going. Not just with this article. I might have to give up on him. Does anyone have a Koehler skeleton-key on offer, to help a dimwit such as myself to understand why he writes, or what he writes about?

I grok, more or less, in toto.
Fractal comprehension.
I revel that as long as we are capable of producing new versions of of our combined selves, we branch consciousness while limiting  cynicism trhough the eyes of tabula rasa, fresh again to the new world born to all, individually.
Refreshing to realize beings created to experience new possibilities from our mistakes. I chance our salvation greater from the dirt stained wide eye wonder war child than  the successor of gifts from countless crushed souls. Beware the bright eyes sharp to cut clouds of carelessness.
A fine essay, though I wish someone had proofread it so that paragraphs are not repeated.  Is anyone at the control panel?

The way I see it this article validates the point that humans have behaved in the same manner of good and evil all over the world in varying degrees since the beginning of our existence. Our ‘evolution’  is sure taking its time. What is also validates is that we can make the best of who we are in the circumstances we find ourselves in as we live lives as full as possible and influence others as best we can.
Lovely!

“Only when I stop knowing what I know do I see the world as it is,”
Yes. Picasso once talked about painting like a child. Without preconceptions we see different truths: a world being born every moment.
Nevertheless we continue to negotiate with the world as we know how. For old truths may be lingering around beside the new; transformed perhaps, but not necessarily replaced.

I so identify with this article.
Seeing with fresh eyes changes the perspective from which we view the world.  Sometimes it takes a jolt of reality–like trying to get a quick lunch on a busy street, to help us look anew.
I am so sad for the loss of your wife Mr. Kohler.  The little girl that said “Barbara is having a baby,” brought back a memory of a lady I took care of (as an RN) in her final days as she was dying of breast cancer.  She said:  I’m in labor now.  Soon it will be time and I will be delivered."  That stuck with me these 20 years.

topic_details.title: How California's Top Democrats Paved the Way for a Republican Governor This Fall

posts.desciription: Originally published at: How California’s Top Democrats Paved the Way for a Republican Governor This Fall

Great work from Norman Solomon, imho. Some people just keep improving, like our old buddy Norman, while others leave some very skanky French Laundry, flapping in the breeze…
I don’t want some nut up there, so I filled in my ballot and sent it back the moment I got it: No, for goodness sake. How did CA wind up with such an insane system, and why is it, when stupid features surface (such as CA’s recall system), we’re perpetually unable to fix anything, ever? It’s like the filibuster, or the Senate: Because it’s stupid, we can’t ever change it.
This happened to Gray Davis, who was outstandingly mediocre, when CA lucked out to stumble upon a decent human being in Schwarzenegger. The problem is on several levels: an idiotic polity playing idiotic games, during very serious times.
The Dixie Fire, now at 2/3 of a million acres, is the first in history to start west of the Sierras, and burn all the way over to the eastern valley. Knock knock knocking on Susanville’s door.

This a political and social tsunami in the making. Elder could win with as little as 20% of the vote if the first box checked is checked yes ( to remove Newsome). No income tax, no mask no matter what, and the National Guard to remove the homeless, etc. would make CA (the) Mississippi on the Pacific overnight. This may be the next chapter in the Republican playbook for minority rule, and the selfish vacuous leadership by Feinstein is precisely the Dem playbook that’ll usher in that rule indistinguishable from the Afghanistan government ceding to the Taliban.

I’m still deciding whether to vote in the recall election.  Either of the two leading Republicans would be terrible.
However, the CDP needs a punch in the face and either of the two possible right wing nutjob replacements would further make a mockery of the GOP and American conservativism in general.

Picked this up from this week’s Roaming Charges column by Jeffery St. Clair, citing an opinion piece in the NYT, raising the same (obvious) flaw i noted, but putting it in a legal context:

Constitutional law scholars Erwin Chemerinsky and Aaron Edlin on the questionable constitutionality of California’s recall election system:

The first question is decided by a majority vote. If a majority favors recalling Mr. Newsom, he is removed from office. But the latter question is decided by a plurality, and whichever candidate gets the most votes, even if it is much less than a majority, becomes the next governor. Critically, Mr. Newsom is not on the ballot for the second question.
By conducting the recall election in this way, Mr. Newsom can receive far more votes than any other candidate but still be removed from office. Many focus on how unfair this structure is to the governor, but consider instead how unfair it is to the voters who support him.

COVID case-fatality for USA has stuck close to 1.7% for awhile (with global case-fatality similarly stable, at 2.2%). I track something I call “immediate mortality” (im) to make clear it’s temporally inappropriate (since people don’t actually die immediately). Merely divide deaths on any line by new-cases over 100, and that’s your im percentage.
The relevance of im to me is just that it’s either pushing USA’s case-fatality a little higher, or a little lower, depending on whether it’s greater or less than 1.7%. At the beginning of July, where the chart above begins, that im ratio is 2.3%. It drops quite a bit, all the way down to 0.47% in mid August, with the Delta surge attaining new strength in new-cases. I’ve been deploying the heavy artillery lately: Thay Nhat Hanh completed a translation of the Heart Sutra, with commentary, exactly 7 years ago – on 8/21/14, called “The Other Shore”. Nearly his final literary work. Something I’ve been saving for a special occasion – times like these.
In this passage, which I thought you might like, Thay describes “letting go”:

The practice of releasing your knowledge is very important in Buddhism. Knowledge is the first obstacle of the mind that a meditator should be able to remove. We should not be too sure of anything.
With knowledge, we obtain more notions and it is difficult to let them go. If we are skillful, we can use new notions like co-arising and interbeing to free ourselves from old notions like birth and death, being and nonbeing. topic_details.title: Why We Urgently Need a Civilian Climate Corps

posts.desciription: Originally published at: Why We Urgently Need a Civilian Climate Corps

It’s a great concept, destined to almost immediately be channeled into Sisyphean efforts such as somehow eliding all the deadwood from our parched forests, where most of the living vegetation here in CA is so dry it hardly matters.
The danger is an abstract idea of “doing something” very often takes off in exactly the wrong direction, where the prime example – already set to go with some “climate corps” concepts – is so-called “forest management”. An incomparable wildfire journalist I’ve grown fond of, Doctor Bill out at WildfireToday, has some points of interest to offer about this Caldor Fire, USA’s top wildfire priority at the moment:


Nothing – no battalion of air-tankers and ground crews – can stop an intense megafire like this; nothing except for merciful weather. (Not likely, but we can hope.)


South Lake Tahoe real estate directly in Caldor’s gunsights is some of the most heavily “managed” you’ll see anywhere. Dr Bill does not sound optimistic about such efforts withstanding circumstances such as embers blowing 1.8 miles.

I’m not that hopeless.
Australian aboriginal tribes live in a real firetrap of an environment.  Long before the English came they used to set offseason fires in their brush.  These fires made safe spots where a tribe could move in case of a megafire, they let new and useful plants grow and they limited any megafire’s spread.
I want to see a new generation of firefighting equipment.  Radio-controlled wheeled robots could add to the total firefighting response without endangering more firefighters.  Put some person in Oshkosh in charge of one robot and give her a task such as watching for fireline-jumping embers and putting them out.
We need to get far more water up to various fire lines, using far less total fossil fuel to get it up there.
I’d like to see quickly deployable ember-stopping nets made of metal fibers or of fiberglass.  I’d like to see fire-insulating covers delivered on trucks and dropped over entire houses, preferably delivered a day early.
In any case, the real forest story is keeping the trees watered in the first place so they don’t burn.  The African Greenbelt project has suggestions for creating single-tree swales that store water, which is better than letting certain megafloods go straight down the river and cause havoc.  California should replace 100% of its non-native Eucalyptus trees, a real pyromaniac species, with better species, and that takes some work.

topic_details.title: Climate Chaos Fueled Death and Destruction of Tennessee Floods: Experts

posts.desciription: Originally published at: Climate Chaos Fueled Death and Destruction of Tennessee Floods: Experts

“With the Earth 2°C warmer than it was in the 1800s, heavier rainstorms have become increasingly frequent while another effect of warmer air—drier soil has made the Earth less able to absorb rain as it inundates a region.”

Technical comment.  I’m a civil engineer with a fair amount of background in hydrology, and dry soils are not “less able to absorb rain” compared to moist soils; they are more able to absorb rain.  Warming is making eastern N. America wetter, resulting in persistently wetter soils which saturate sooner in a heavy rain and produce more storm runoff, making flooding worse (along with more frequent landslides).
The author is probably thinking of the rapid flooding from storm in desert areas, but that is not due to “dry soil”, it is due to little vegetation, and little soil at all - the rain falling mostly on rock and very rocky soil.

To your point, one concern about the deep drought in the southwest is that water from ephemeral creeks etc. is not making it to the Colorado river in the same quantities as in the past.  It’s being soaked up, sponge style, by dry soils.
